title: Divider
description: A divider is a thin line that groups content in lists and containers.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Dividers can reinforce tapability, such as when used to separate list items or define tappable regions in an accordion.

contentChunks.footer: Dividers separating items in a list.
contentChunks.altText: Screen shot of five stacked dividers

Takeaways

• Dividers should be noticeable in a layout, but not jarring
  • Dividers should only be used if elements cannot be separated using white space
  • Use dividers sparingly, to create groupings rather than separate items
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Configurations: Ability to have vertical dividers

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

Design guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for usage, behavior, responsive layout, and more.
Usage

Dividers are one way to visually group components and create hierarchy. They can also be used to imply nested parent/child relationships.

There are two types of dividers: 

  1. Full width
  2. Inset
Anatomy
A divider is a simple line.
Full width dividers

Use full width dividers to separate larger sections of unrelated content. They can be used directly on a surface or inside other components like cards or lists.

Full width dividers can also separate interactive areas from non-interactive areas. 

They are used to group visual elements together, and indicate when elements are related to each other from an interaction perspective.

contentChunks.footer: Full width dividers to indicate separation of content.
Use full-width divider lines to separate interactive and non-interactive areas of a container such as a card.
Use full-width dividers sparingly. Too many divider lines will make an interface look cluttered.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Inset dividers

Use inset dividers to separate related content within a section.

Inset dividers are equally indented from both sides of the screen by default.

contentChunks.footer: Inset dividers separate related content, such as emails in a list. They should be used with anchoring elements such as icons or avatars, and align with the leading edge of the screen.
Inset dividers in a list of related items.
Inset dividers can be placed in the middle of a layout to separate elements such as body text from selection chips.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Using both types of dividers on the same screen

If both types of dividers are used in a UI, they must reinforce the hierarchy of information within different sections.

  1. To separate a different type of content, use a full-width divider
  2. To separate nested content items, use inset dividers

contentChunks.footer: Use a combination of inset and full width dividers to reflect the hierarchy of information.

contentChunks.htmlValue: List items with repetitive formats may not require an inset divider, in which using only the margin between items is acceptable.

contentChunks.footer: Content may not require a divider line.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
Dividers are decorative elements and have no minimum contrast requirements.

contentChunks.footer: Decorative elements have no minimum contrast requirements.
contentChunks.altText: Dividers separating messages in an inbox that are already separated with type styles and spacing is annotated as decorative
